active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a fast-paced agile development environment, how should teams balance the frequency of security risk register updates with sprint deadlines? Debate the pros and cons of daily, weekly, or milestone-based updates, and propose a hybrid schedule using NIST SP 800-37 Rev 2 guidelines for continuous monitoring. Support your position with examples from application security risks like zero-day vulnerabilities.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Students pair up. Partner A explains the core components of a security risk register (risk ID, likelihood, impact, mitigation status, owner per NIST SP 800-30) using a sample entry from an application security context (e.g., SQL injection risk). Partner B listens, asks clarifying questions, then 'teaches back' by creating and explaining their own example (e.g., XSS vulnerability). Switch roles and discuss integration into SDLC phases.
active_learning.problem_solving: Scenario: A deployed web application faces a new zero-day vulnerability similar to Log4Shell. Provide students with a partially completed risk register template (including existing risks). In small groups, students: 1) Identify and add the new risk; 2) Reassess likelihood/impact for related entries; 3) Prioritize mitigations (e.g., patching, monitoring); 4) Track changes and assign owners. Collaborate via shared document and present updates, justifying decisions against NIST frameworks.
